stream_context.summary: Kaze works on Course 14’s ‘cardboard-box to hell’ set-piece: replacing a zipper idea with a tape-pull mechanism, animating the tape as an actor, fixing a Bowser-holding bug, and optimizing the level’s performance. He also talks about upcoming Yoshi side-missions and a video on rewriting Mario 64.

development_findings.summary: Scrapped Biobak’s original zipper concept and switched to a tape strip the player pulls to open the cardboard box and drop into a ‘hell’ area, because a zipper felt thematically unfitting and technologically show-offy.
development_findings.quote: I don't want to make a rom-hack exhibiting random technology. A piece of tape you can pull fits better than a zipper.

development_findings.summary: The tape will be a single animated actor that lengthens as Mario pulls it. Kaze experiments with segment count, vertex animation, and thin geometry to keep rendering cost low.
Performance for the stage improved dramatically after discovering draw distance was set to ‘infinite’; he reduced draw range and merged mountain decals into one material.
development_findings.quote: The reason it ran poorly is because… I still had the drawing distance for everything set at infinite.

development_findings.summary: Implemented an HD Mario model with fewer triangles but higher-res textures, 3-D buttons, a jiggle-nose, and a colored shoe line.
Created a red ‘glow to hell’ under the box opening and adjusted collision gaps so players can peek inside before jumping.

Planned 45 optional ‘Yoshi star’ missions that behave like Mario Galaxy’s comets—bonus stars with special constraints (e.g., red coins with ≤2 A-presses). Yoshi will not appear in the next public demo.
development_findings.quote: We've done Yoshi's Island has that but with Yoshi stars instead… I'm planning 45 of those in total.

development_findings.summary: Fixed a Bowser-holding glitch: action argument was overwritten to 0 only in this level and only on Project 64. Root cause was code treating action arg and action state interchangeably during intro-scene reset.
development_findings.quote: They really just use action arg and action state interchangeably – vanilla bro likes his tea.

development_findings.summary: Preparing a YouTube video titled ‘Why I’ve Been Rewriting Mario 64,’ explaining the wholesale code rewrite he has undertaken.

context_findings.summary: Believes Germany is ‘one of the worst countries to live in’; currently lives in Canada.
context_findings.quote: Germany is the worst country to live in in the entire world… maybe not the very worst, but it's in my top 10.

context_findings.summary: Celebrates earning significant ad revenue from Twitter impressions and actively ‘min-maxes’ social media metrics.
context_findings.quote: The Twitter monetization grind is going way better than I thought. We hit 250k today… we’re making a hell of a bank off Twitter.

context_findings.summary: Has the entire week off and expects to stream almost daily, integrating workout time on-stream.
Expresses frustration and confusion while debugging emulator-specific bugs, but satisfaction once fixes and performance gains are achieved.

biobak.summary: Suggested using a zipper for the box-opening mechanic; Kaze considered it before rejecting the idea.
Engages in chat about Twitter analytics and plays numerous Wordle-like games; portrayed as a constant tester/audience for Kaze’s work.

key_stories.title: Choosing the Box-Opening Mechanic
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed a way for Mario to open a giant cardboard box that hides the entrance to a hell area. Biobak first proposed a zipper, but it felt out of place and technologically flashy. After brainstorming staples and knives, Kaze lands on a pull-tape solution.
key_stories.challenge: Find a thematically appropriate, technically feasible method for opening the box.
key_stories.process: Weighed zipper, staples, knife, and tape; assessed animation cost and aesthetic fit; decided on thin, vertex-animated tape.
key_stories.outcome: Tape actor will animate as Mario pulls it, revealing the drop and suiting the craft aesthetic.
key_stories.key_quote: A zipper feels so unfitting… a piece of tape you can pull might actually be better.

key_stories.title: The Bowser Hold Bug
key_stories.summary: Mario dropped Bowser unexpectedly when testing the new level, and the issue appeared only on Project 64. Kaze traced the bug to code that reset the intro cut-scene and inadvertently zeroed the action argument.
key_stories.challenge: Figure out why Mario lets go of Bowser in Course 14 on one emulator but not another.
key_stories.process: Used breakpoints on action arg, compared Nemu and Project 64 behaviour, discovered action arg/state confusion.
key_stories.outcome: Patched code to use action state properly; holding Bowser now works consistently.
key_stories.key_quote: Something is overwriting the action arg only in this level… vanilla bro likes his tea.
